title: Understanding Logarithmic Functions
text: The natural logarithm function, ln(x), is only defined for positive values of $$x$$. This means that whatever is inside the logarithm (the argument) must be greater than zero.

title: Identify the Inner Function
text: For the function $$g(x)=\ln(2x+6)-5$$, the argument of the ln function is $$2x+6$$. We need to ensure that this expression is greater than zero to determine the domain of g(x).

title: Solve for $$x$$
text: Set the argument $$2x+6$$ greater than zero and solve for $$x$$ to find the domain. Once you find the critical point where $$x$$ causes the argument to be zero, determine the domain. Please enter your answer as $$x>a$$ where a is the solution to the equation.

title: Vertical Asymptote Characteristics
text: Vertical asymptotes occur where the logarithmic function tends towards negative $$\infty$$. This usually happens when the argument equals zero, since ln(0) is undefined.

title: Determine the Vertical Asymptote
text: To find the vertical asymptote, set the argument $$2x+6$$ equal to zero and solve for $$x$$. This value indicates the x-coordinate where the vertical asymptote occurs. Please enter your answer in the form $$x=a$$ where a is the solution.

title: Summarizing Domain and Asymptote
text: Review the solutions for the domain and vertical asymptote. Which pair correctly represents the domain and vertical asymptote for $$g(x)=\ln(2x+6)-5$$?
